newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, First Data form Internet venture.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, First Data form Internet venture.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. said Thursday it has formed a joint venture with First Data Corp. to allow companies to send bills and receive payments from consumers via the Internet.
Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.
The service, called MSFDC, will be the first of its kind to provide an end-to-end system for electronic presentation of bills, Microsoft said.
Field tests of the service with banks and billers will start this summer and it is to be introduced early next year.
"MSFDC is an important part of Microsoft's strategy to further electronic commerce on the Internet," said Bill Gates, chief executive officer of Microsoft.

The venture will also allow users to pay creditors who do not present their bills electronically. This service enables financial institutions to increase the feature content of their home-banking services while lowering the cost.
The venture, based in Denver, will have its own management, sales and marketing team. The board of directors includes representatives from both Microsoft and First Data.
Microsoft and First Data have formed an advisory board to help evaluate customer needs, develop products and services, and satisfy regulatory and information-security requirements.
Founding members of the advisory board include leading financial institutions, American Express Co., BankAmerica Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp., Citicorp and Wells Fargo.
Industry groups include the American Gas Association, representing gas utilities, Edison Electric Institute, representing electric utilities and U.S. Telephone Association.
Microsoft stock fell 87.5 cents to $129.56 on Nasdaq in early afternoon trading. First Data rose 25 cents to $42.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
